#Edifess3443
On the topic of gender: I get that it's something new and it'll take a while to adjust. What I don't get is why people need to mock those who aren't cis and make a point of not accepting it. These people aren't pretending to be a different gender to get attention, this is how they feel: being born into the wrong body is traumatic and having the world saying you're making it up for attention makes it so much worse. Does it really matter to cis people, does it affect your lives in anyway apart from having to be slightly more accepting. Also, NEWSFLASH nobody is wanting a female or gender neutral Santa: the media is pushing this so that feminists and the trans/gender neutral movement are mocked and not taken seriously.
post_text:

text:
#Edifess3392
The library now has the distinct feeling of a club still open at 4am. Most have left, the music is dying down and the drinks are running low. The average sanity level of those still there is dropping continuously, and yet a beautiful sense of calm is widespread. Some unverifiable reports heard today suggested that someone had seen a smile from a stranger. Yet more bizarre was the report that the word 'Yah' has not been heard on the fourth floor for at least 23 hours. We cannot verify these reports but we do at this stage recommend avoiding wearing active wear in the library for fear of sticking out.

#Edifess3354
A while ago, I was walking up the stairs in the library to the second floor when I passed the most beautiful guy. He had long hair I seem to remember, and the warmest eyes and presence about him. I hope it's not a romanticized memory.
I looked at him and he looked at me, I think in passing. And then when I got to the top of the stairs, I looked back at him for a second and saw him looking back at me. Not wanting to imagine it all, I sat down at a computer.
Then I realized I had a sock stuck by static to the inside of my fleece which was open. I don't know how it got there. That probably explains why I thought he smiled at me. I am so bumbling every day! But I wanted to say whoever it was I thought you looked lovely and wonderful.

Is struggling with mental health a legitimate reason to leave university? I want a degree and i do enjoy my degree, but i can't work at my best when in a bad place mentally. I am already signed up with the disability service and i meet a mental health mentor regularly. Even with this in place, university is so so hard. An alternative to leaving would be asking for extensions on work but i have never had to do that and i would feel a bit like a failure. I feel like to study here and be on this course i should be able to cope. I don't want to apply to special circumstances for the same reason as with extensions, but i have had special circumstances before. Anyone else been in the same boat or can give me advice on what to do?

text:
#Edifess3244
I’ve had this thing with a guy, on and off for like a year, we’ve both been kinda shit to each other but it’s obvious that I like him more and he’s treated me worse than I have him. Recently it’s started to get better and we have actually been seeing each other often and it’s been really nice, just chatting and having fun - actual dates, seeing each other’s friends etc. I’ve been thinking that this might be it, and we might start a relationship. He’s still is quite flaky and makes me feel quite insecure all the time - as if he just gonna stop talking to me and start seeing another girl (which he’s done multiple times in the past because I couldn’t see him for a few weeks bc of exams). Anyway, this week I’ve barely spoken to him, I’ve tried to start a conversation a few times, and although I know he’s a horrible texter and even though he has always replied to me, I just have been feeling really insecure. It seems like he’s starting to retract again, I was scared he was going to fuck off again. Basically, I went out and got completely pissed n a little bit high n went home with his flatmates best friend. I dunno whether to tell him because I unsure whether or not we’re basically over. He never definitively says we’re over, he just drifts away and then calls me up in a month to say he’s sorry and misses me. Also, if I tell him he could potentially get angry with his flatmates friend and I don’t want the other guy in trouble because he’s lovely. Anyway, to sum up, pretty much obsessed with a boy who is lovely but can make feel so insecure because of the way he’s treated me and the things he’s done. I slept with a friends of his and don’t know whether to tell him because I have a feeling it’s coming to the end of the “thing” anyway. I don’t want it to end tbh because I really like him but I know my feelings for him aren’t justified because rationally he’s not good for me, and considering what I just did, I’m probably not good for him either. How do I get over him? Should I tell him if we’re not over and do you think I should continue to see him if we’re not - I just feel so drawn to him, I’ve never wanted to be with anyone so much.

Confused by the Go Abroad process?
On your year abroad right now and struggling?
Visiting Edinburgh as an exchange and finding things hard?
DID YA GO ABROAD AND HAVE A GOOD/SHIT TIME?
If you're thinking about going on your year abroad, currently are on it (or are a visiting student) or are back in Edinburgh after it, we want to hear from you.
We all know the system has got some serious flaws and that many students have felt neglected by Edinburgh uni - so come along to our meetings in the new year where we want to make some genuine changes (there will also be some monetary incentives, and tea/coffee and cake for everyone).
Like our page to keep updated - https://www.facebook.com/ourjourneygoabroaduofed/
post_text:
#Edifess2593
Confused by the Go Abroad process?
On your year abroad right now and struggling?
Visiting Edinburgh as an exchange and finding things hard?
DID YA GO ABROAD AND HAVE A GOOD/SHIT TIME?
If you're thinking about going on your year abroad, currently are on it (or are a visiting student) or are back in Edinburgh after it, we want to hear from you.
We all know the system has got some serious flaws and that many students have felt neglected by Edinburgh uni - so come along to our meetings in the new year where we want to make some genuine changes (there will also be some monetary incentives, and tea/coffee and cake for everyone).
Like our page to keep updated - https://www.facebook.com/ourjourneygoabroaduofed/

#Edifess2598
Now this is a confession I have to make. I feel kinda guilty about this but I want your thoughts.
I left the George Square Campus and came across a homeless person. She directly asked for money. I actually had no change on me at all and I only had my card. Instead, I offered her food. But she rejected it. I said I haven’t got any change on me and I would be happy to go and buy her lunch.
She abruptly said “No, No need” and I asked if she was sure. Now for some reason, she simply told me to Fuck off. At this point I honestly thought she was a fake beggar. But thinking about it, I do believe there was a slight language barrier so it is possible she misinterpreted what I said.
I want to ask for your thoughts guys. Did I do the right thing by atleast offering lunch? Please give constructive criticism if you feel I done something wrong. Thanks.

text:
#Edifess2513
Getting a seat in the library is a lot like monopoly; some seats are just inherently better than others.
For instance, if you're looking for Mayfair, or Park Lane, look no further than the laptop seating areas on the southside of the 4th floor, overlooking the Pentland mountain range and Meadows. I say 4th specifically because 4th has the hottest girls. After these, your Oxford Streets and your Piccadillies are on the 5th, which is still nice but has a weird smell to it and is eerily quiet.
There's a lot of interchange for most of the other floors, and these are up to your own interpretation. But there's no disputing that sitting at the Quick Use computers with your laptop out is definitely the brown properties whose names nobody gives a shit about.
Oh, and the Lower Ground floor is jail. Without a doubt. It's just fucking depressing.

#Edifess2380
I am sorry to everyone I hurt by the sexual harassment post. I didn't mean to be so ignorant.
What I tried to say was along the lines of "When it is reported to security, security should post something such as "Please be careful around xyz area..., look out for a xyz wearing xyz in this area" " just to let others be aware and to let the attacker know that people know where they are so chances are they won't do it again. I'm sure that they can find other places but I just thought that if people know to be aware in certain areas where attackers are comfortable, that area could be ruled out.
I believe the more I say about this, the more I put my foot in my mouth and I am going to offend someone. It is not my intention and I was simply trying to think of ways to help. I am sorry.

#Edifess2214
So Edifess, I need you to help clarify something for me…
A while ago I was seeing this girl a few years younger than me. It was a fairly casual, we would only see each other every now and again what with me being very busy with work.
Don’t ask me how it came up (we had some very strange pillow talk) but after sex one time it came up that she was keeping all her savings and inheritance in an instant-access savings account with a very uncompetitive interest rate.
I told her this was a foolish idea and that she was losing money to inflation. I gave her some advice on how better to save and helped set her up with a much better account. She is now receiving a handsome yearly income as thanks to me all her money is in a tax efficient stocks and shares ISA containing high dividend yield index funds. Not gonna lie, I think this display of economic maturity really got her going and we started having way more kinky sex. I guess what I’m wondering is, does this make me a sugar daddy?

text:
#Edifess1242
#Edifess1237
First off, people who genuinely experience dysphoria, especially regarding things that are very rigid in our society (such as gender and race) typically suffer a great deal as a result, and all too often in complete silence.
Unfortunately, this dysphoria cannot be lifted by simply “snapping one’s fingers” (which is, by the way, quite a passive-aggressive turn of phrase in this context), though I’m sure those living with it sometimes wish it were that way. If you are genuinely concerned about perverts identifying as transgender in order to harm others, rest assured in that you can now easily distinguish between perverts and transgender people with this simple rule: If snapping their fingers is all takes for them to feel they have “changed their gender”, they may indeed be a pervert. Meanwhile, people who are transgender live with the reality that identifying as such and relieving their dysphoria is usually a process, not a spontaneous decision involving finger snappage. I am a woman, I can tell the difference between the two, and as a result I do not feel threatened by transgender people and am happy for them to use the facilities that correspond to the gender they identify as.
Finally, and probably most importantly in the context of your argument, perverts are perverts. They have never needed an excuse to do the things they do, and I do not believe that this will change now that the majority of our society is accepting of transgender people. Despite how far we’ve come, do you realize how difficult it still is to come out (both to yourself and society) and identify as transgender!? (Apparently, pretty fucking difficult!) Personally, if I was a pervert, that would sound like way too much effort to be worth it. I’d probably just continue to be pervy without remorse or the need for an excuse.
However, I too am open to being ‘enlightened’, and would much appreciate it if you could (kindly) point me to a legitimate source claiming that a significant number of perverts have been found slinking into changing rooms/toilets and claiming to be transgender.
(Side-note: I find it quite interesting that your go-to description of a transgender woman is someone who wears traditionally feminine clothing, indicating that you either have a shallow understanding of the many layers of being transgender (it goes way beyond physical appearance), believe that transgender people have a very limited understanding of gender expression, or (most likely) both.)
On an unrelated note:
Mr. Natas = Satan
Defeat him by using your explosives and repair nanobots!

First off, people who genuinely experience dysphoria, especially regarding things that are very rigid in our society (such as gender and race) typically suffer a great deal as a result, and all too often in complete silence.
Unfortunately, this dysphoria cannot be lifted by simply “snapping one’s fingers” (which is, by the way, quite a passive-aggressive turn of phrase in this context), though I’m sure those living with it sometimes wish it were that way. If you are genuinely concerned about perverts identifying as transgender in order to harm others, rest assured in that you can now easily distinguish between perverts and transgender people with this simple rule: If snapping their fingers is all takes for them to feel they have “changed their gender”, they may indeed be a pervert. Meanwhile, people who are transgender live with the reality that identifying as such and relieving their dysphoria is usually a process, not a spontaneous decision involving finger snappage. I am a woman, I can tell the difference between the two, and as a result I do not feel threatened by transgender people and am happy for them to use the facilities that correspond to the gender they identify as.
Finally, and probably most importantly in the context of your argument, perverts are perverts. They have never needed an excuse to do the things they do, and I do not believe that this will change now that the majority of our society is accepting of transgender people. Despite how far we’ve come, do you realize how difficult it still is to come out (both to yourself and society) and identify as transgender!? (Apparently, pretty fucking difficult!) Personally, if I was a pervert, that would sound like way too much effort to be worth it. I’d probably just continue to be pervy without remorse or the need for an excuse.
However, I too am open to being ‘enlightened’, and would much appreciate it if you could (kindly) point me to a legitimate source claiming that a significant number of perverts have been found slinking into changing rooms/toilets and claiming to be transgender.
(Side-note: I find it quite interesting that your go-to description of a transgender woman is someone who wears traditionally feminine clothing, indicating that you either have a shallow understanding of the many layers of being transgender (it goes way beyond physical appearance), believe that transgender people have a very limited understanding of gender expression, or (most likely) both.)
On an unrelated note:
Mr. Natas = Satan
Defeat him by using your explosives and repair nanobots!

text:
#Edifess1137
To all people from england who call themselves 'northeners' and waltz around on this fact:
Piss off
You're not northerners, you're using a slang word as a fucking knighthood in an attempt to gain some imaginary respect that apparently you get if you're a 'true northerner'. You're not from the north and you don't come from a 'rough area'; you likely have a posh accent and you live further south than half the fucking country. You make fun of people from southern england in an attempt to throw them to the wolves to save yourselves from the fact that you're exactly the same as them.
You had a 'tough time' working good hours and a half-decent paying job to get to university with help from the bank of parents, and now it's hard to pay for all of your blue wkds; which would be fine if you just accepted the fact that you're well off and didn't pretend like you got a tough break just because you're 'from the north'.
Also, when making game of thrones references about the north, a word of advice.
Don't.
As a highlander, the analogy runs dry all too quickly when you think that having a medium sized sainsbury's and a shitty little park 5 mins from your house is 'living the wild life'. Try having frequent power cuts, non-stop rain, a 1 hour drive to any decent sized shop, and chopping firewood in a swarm of midges during what's meant to be summer but feels like death, literally just to stay warm during the winter. I personally am not in a rough position where I'm fighting financially to stay in education, but chances are, you 'northerners' aren't either. People genuinely in financial struggle aren't worried about if people see them as northerners, they're too busy worrying about paying to stay alive...
Wholesome morals to take from this half-joking post:
- Don't bullshit yourself and others, it's unhealthy for you and a dick move to others.
- Don't be so ashamed of your background that you have to exaggerate yourself to be someone you're not. Help and sympathize with those who actually need support instead.
- Remember that no decent person gives a fuck where you're from.
- Feel free to absolutely judge people on what they say and do. Go berserk. Just not on what their situation is.
Final note to all triggered 'northeners': I'm not judging, or doing anything I said not to, to anyone from northern england. I'm judging the people who boast about it. Like yourself. No one gives a fuck that you're from yorkshire

text:
#Edifess220
#Edifess204
Hey, sorry to hear you're feeling homesick! Firstly, it's completely normal to feel this way - most students will go through it at some point. You are allowed to feel sad and homesick and you are also allowed to enjoy yourself – it isn’t being disloyal the people you miss! Times of feeling low, stressed and anxious are part and parcel of moving away. There is always a period of adjustment that people go through when faced with any change. Here are some tips to deal with homesickness:
- Talk to someone! I promise we're friendly (most of us anyway). If anyone approached me feeling this way, I'd be more than happy to sit with them and talk about it. If you haven’t yet made friends yet, then try a tutor, supervisor, chaplain, older students (I know we can be a wee bit intimidating) or a member of the Student Wellbeing Team. Remember that many other people will be feeling the same way, even though you may assume that they are doing fine.
- Give yourself time to adjust. You don’t have to get everything right straight away.
- Keep in touch with family and friends form back home, but don't forget to fully immerse yourself in student life and get involved with societies/sports etc. Don’t let looking back actually hinder moving forward.
- Invite friends and family to visit - maybe not straight away but after the first month, encourage friends and family to come and see you in your new home.
- Remember to get enough food and sleep! They affect us both emotionally and physically.
- Meet up with other people. Make contacts and friends through shared activities such as sport or other interests. There are so many clubs and societies within the uni and city that you are pretty much guaranteed to find something to suit your interests. Try something new. Keep active. It will take your mind off feeling homesick!
- Make yourself at home. Make your room as comfortable as possible… unpack and decorate with some comforts from home. Have friends over from other flats!
- Remember to look after yourself and be aware of when you’re feeling down. The uni's Health and Wellbeing team are always here to support you.
- Lastly, if you're struggling with homesickness or any other issues - feel free to message the admin. They love juicy gossip and a good roast but they're also a bunch of super friendly people who have helped me and a few other students out :)

text:
#Edifess115
#Edifess103 #Edifess104
The Higher Education Policy Institute calculated Gini coefficients for the Participation of Local Areas (POLAR) in the 2016 UG admissions cycle. They ranked all UK higher education institutions in terms of their coefficients. A coefficient of 0 means that the institution is “perfectly equal” and a coefficient of 1 means that the institution is “perfectly unequal”.
“The best measure on equity of participation in the UK is the POLAR (Participation of Local Areas) system. Based on the higher education participation rates for individual areas, the POLAR system ranks wards according to their participation rates and then divides them into five groups (quintiles), each of which holds an equal proportion of the young cohort. The quintiles are numbered 1 to 5, with quintile 1 areas having the lowest participation rates and quintile 5 the highest.”
The University of Edinburgh: 0.42
Edinburgh Napier University: 0.35
For context the best in the UK was the University of Hull with a coefficient of 0.03 and the worst was the University of Cambridge with a coefficient of 0.48. The average for a UK institution was 0.18.
BOTH of the universities have issues with class and University of Edinburgh is the superior university in terms of academia in almost every measure (See QS world rankings and methodology). It is not as simple as classifying students as classist when the university they are criticising for being less academic also have a MAJOR problem with admitting students from working class backgrounds.
HEPI Report:
https://www.hepi.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HEPI-Policy-Note-6-Benchmarking-widening-participation-FINAL.pdf
QS World University Rankings:
https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2018
